#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make a Simple Solar Viewer
#Text=You have probably been told never to look directly at the sun , but that begs the question “ How do you study it ? ”
#Text=The sun is very intense and can do serious damage to your eyes if you gaze at it for even a moment .
#Text=Luckily , astronomers have a few tricks for getting around this .
#Text=The most common way is to use a solar viewer , which allows you to see the sun 's image on a piece of paper or cardboard .
#Text=They are easy and inexpensive to make and use , and they give you the ability to safely study the sun .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Building a Pinhole Camera
#Text=Cut a square in a cardboard box .
#Text=Cut into the short side of a cardboard box .
#Text=This way , the light shining through the hole can travel the length of the box to the other side .
#Text=Letting the light travel the length of the box will enlarge the image .
#Text=You should use a box that is no less than long to produce a clear , viewable image .
#Text=If you do not have a cardboard box that is long , you can cut smaller pieces of cardboard and tape or glue them together to make a box that is the appropriate length .
#Text=Make sure the pieces are joined completely and that no light shines through the places where they are connected .
#Text=Cover the square with aluminum foil .
#Text=Tape a piece of aluminum foil over the hole in the box .
#Text=Aluminum foil will block excess light from shining through the hole you created .
#Text=Be sure that the foil is pulled tight so that it is smooth .
#Text=Make a small hole in the foil .
#Text=Use a toothpick or a needle to prick a hole in the center of the aluminum foil .
#Text=This will allow just a small amount of light to be focused through the hole and projected at the other end of the box .
#Text=This will provide an image of the sun that is safe to look at .
#Text=Projecting the Image
#Text=Tape up your screen .
#Text=To improve the quality of your image , you can project it on a white screen .
#Text=The easiest way to do this is to take blank white paper and tape it at the end of the viewer ( furthest from the hole ) .
#Text=One sheet of paper is sufficient .
#Text=Aim the pinhole at the sun .
#Text=In order for your viewer to capture the an image of the sun , you have to aim it .
#Text=Avoid looking at the sun to aim the viewer .
#Text=Instead , point the viewer in the general direction of the sun and then move it around slowly until you see the sun on your screen .
#Text=View the image of the sun .
#Text=Once you have the sun on your screen , it is safe to look at .
#Text=You do not need any safety glasses or other special equipment .
#Text=The image is much less intense than actually looking at the sun .
#Text=Studying the Sun
#Text=Be safe .
#Text=You should never look directly at the sun .
#Text=Even doing so briefly can damage your eyes .
#Text=You have to use a solar viewer to project the image or buy special glasses and/or telescopes that filter out enough light to be safe .
#Text=Sunglasses will NOT protect your eyes from the sun .
#Text=Only special filtered lenses will be safe .
#Text=Watch for patterns .
#Text=If you are serious about studying the sun , you can watch for patterns .
#Text=Look for sunspots in your image ( they will show up as dimmer spots on the image ) .
#Text=Observe the sunspots over time and see how they move .
#Text=To make accurate comparisons , you should observe the sun from the same place every time .
#Text=Brush up on your math skills .
#Text=You can use some basic measurements of your image and viewer to find interesting facts about the sun .
#Text=This is because the image you are viewing is a scaled down image of the sun .
#Text=Even though it 's smaller , it is proportional to the actual sun .
#Text=For example , you can find the diameter of the sun by following these steps :
#Text=Divide the diameter of the image by the distance from the pinhole ( the length of the box ) .
#Text=Multiply that answer by the distance between the earth and sun ( approximately 150,000,000 kilometers or 93,000,000 miles )
#Text=Find other ways to watch the sun .
#Text=You can watch the sun without a specially made solar viewer .
#Text=Find a tree or other object that provides shade .
#Text=If there are any holes or spaces in the object , you can study the spots of sun that shine through .
#Text=You can also hold your hands up and study the sunlight that shines through the spaces between your fingers .
#Text=Put white paper or cardboard under whatever you are using to view the sunlight and look at the image of the sun on the paper or cardboard .
#Text=Keep in mind that you should never look directly at the sun .
#Text=Tips
#Text=The image of the sun will be small , but you can adjust the size of this image by moving the screen back and forth .
#Text=Moving the viewer away from the screen will make the image larger , but blurrier .
#Text=You can study other celestial bodies using a telescope .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Never look directly at the sun .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Cardboard box
#Text=Aluminum foil
#Text=Tape
#Text=Toothpick
#Text=Scissors
#Text=Ruler ( for measuring )
#Text=Pen or marker
#Text=Paper ( white )
